title: 113_hr401
content: The Act may be cited as the "Justice and Mental Health Collaboration Act of 2013" and includes provisions for assisting veterans. The "Justice and Mental Health Collaboration Act of 2013" includes provisions for assisting veterans by amending Section 2991 of the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 to provide peer to peer services or programs for qualified veterans. The term 'qualified veteran' refers to a former offender who served in the Armed Forces and was discharged under honorable conditions. A 'veterans treatment court program' involves collaboration between criminal justice, veterans, and mental health agencies to provide intensive supervision and support for qualified veterans. The Attorney General, in consultation with the Secretary of Veterans Affairs, oversees a veterans assistance program that includes case management, a full range of treatment services, alternatives to incarceration, and other support services such as housing, transportation, mentoring, and job training. The Attorney General, in consultation with the Secretary of Veterans Affairs, may award grants to establish veterans treatment court programs, peer to peer services for veterans, practices for incarcerated veterans, and training programs for criminal justice personnel. The Attorney General may award grants for veterans treatment court programs, peer to peer services, practices for incarcerated veterans, and training programs for criminal justice personnel, with priority given to applications that demonstrate collaboration and effective strategies to improve outcomes for qualified veterans. SEC. 3. CORRECTIONAL FACILITIES. Section 2991 of the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 is amended to include definitions related to correctional facilities and eligible inmates with mental illness. The Attorney General may award grants to correctional facilities to enhance capabilities in identifying and screening eligible inmates, providing assessments of clinical, medical, and social needs, offering appropriate treatment for mental health and substance abuse, and developing post-release transition plans. The Attorney General may award grants to correctional facilities for post-release transition plans coordinating health, housing, employment, mental health services, substance abuse treatment, and alternatives to solitary confinement. Employees are trained to identify and respond to inmate needs. The Attorney General may award grants to correctional facilities for post-release transition plans coordinating health, housing, employment, mental health services, substance abuse treatment, and alternatives to solitary confinement. Employees are trained to identify and appropriately respond to incidents involving inmates with mental health or co-occurring mental health and substance abuse disorders. SEC. 4. HIGH UTILIZERS. Section 2991 of the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 is amended to include a new subsection (k) for Demonstration Grants Responding to High Utilizers. A high utilizer is defined as an individual with mental illness who consumes a disproportionate amount of public resources. The Attorney General may award up to 6 grants per year under this subsection. The Attorney General may award up to 6 grants per year under a new subsection for Demonstration Grants Responding to High Utilizers. Recipients can use the grants to develop multidisciplinary teams and provide training for public service personnel on handling high utilizers. The Attorney General may award grants for Demonstration Grants Responding to High Utilizers to develop multidisciplinary teams and provide training for public service personnel on handling high utilizers in various sectors such as healthcare, law enforcement, corrections, and housing. The grants aim to support alternatives to hospital and jail admissions for high utilizers and develop coordinated assistance protocols among different service operations. The recipient of a grant awarded under this subsection must submit a report to the Attorney General within one year, measuring their performance in reducing the use of public services by high utilizers and providing a model for other jurisdictions to adopt. SEC. 5. ACADEMY TRAINING. Section 2991(h) of the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 is amended to provide support for academy training programs that teach law enforcement personnel how to identify and respond to incidents involving persons with mental health disorders or co-occurring disorders. Priority consideration will be given to programs developed by law enforcement personnel and mental health professionals when awarding grants under this subsection. The Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 is amended to support academy training programs for law enforcement to identify and respond to incidents involving individuals with mental health disorders. Priority is given to programs developed cooperatively by law enforcement and mental health professionals. SEC. 6. EVIDENCE BASED PRACTICES. Amends the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act to propose interventions proven to reduce recidivism and use validated tools to target offenders at risk. SEC. 7. SAFE COMMUNITIES. Section 2991(a) of the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 is amended to include the definition of "preliminarily qualified offender" as an individual accused of an offense with a mental health disorder. The "preliminarily qualified offender" is defined as an individual accused of an offense who has been diagnosed with a mental illness or substance abuse disorder, or shows obvious signs of these conditions during arrest or confinement. This definition also applies to individuals in veterans treatment courts who have been diagnosed with or show signs of mental illness or substance abuse disorders. The "preliminarily qualified offender" designation requires unanimous approval from relevant parties including prosecuting attorney, defense attorney, probation or corrections official, judge, and a representative from the mental health agency. The relevant parties involved in determining the participation of a defendant in a program include the prosecuting attorney, defense attorney, probation or corrections official, judge, and a representative from a mental health or substance abuse agency. Factors considered include the risk of violence to the community, criminal history, offense severity, victim views, defendant's benefit from the program, and community impact. The defendant's eligibility for program participation is determined by a group of relevant parties, including prosecuting attorney, defense attorney, probation or corrections official, judge, and a mental health or substance abuse agency representative. Factors considered include cost savings for the community and meeting established eligibility criteria. The eligibility for program participation is determined by various parties based on cost savings and meeting eligibility criteria. The offense must not involve the use of physical force or pose a substantial risk of force being used. SEC. 8. REAUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Subsection (l) of section 2991 of the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 is amended to allocate $40,000,000 for each fiscal year from 2015 to 2019. Additionally, a limitation is set that not more than 20 percent of the funds can be used for purposes related to veterans.
